review:
I really hope I bought this game as part of an indie bundle, or I got myself very ripped off in the past.

The premise sounds good. Pixel art, zombies, running a gun store, explosions!!! 
But you start and it gets bad pretty fast. Every single trailer video and photo is pretty much a lie.
Gameplay is relatively simple if shallow and extremely buggy.  

You get a one minute tutorial explaining that you should build all your initial buildings. These include:
Bed to sleep in at night. 
Storage box to store your guns. 
Cash register to buy/sell guns. 
Bar/Gambling table to generate passive income and attract Mercenaries and generals. 

Then you can go off script and build a few extra things
A stool for decoration
Turrets that shoot at zombies
A map to send your mercenaries into the wild. Never to return.

Expect to go through this tutorial every time you start up the game because the game is actually a Roguelike.
The save game button says it saves the game, but I can't verify that as the load game button is actually just another way to quit the game.

Gameplay involves choosing to buy guns at a discount and sell them at a profit. The higher the profit margin, the more times you need to play the minigame. This minigame is to press the button when the arrow points to the shaded region. The game sometimes stutters to add some extra difficulty. I cannot tell if this is intended or not.

Another twist in the game is that you are a very generous vendor. So if someone buys a gun from you, you give them every copy of that gun in your inventory. Maybe that was intended by the developer to add a memory aspect to the difficulty. 

You hire mercenaries that come with random guns. Some might have dinky pistols while others have sniper rifles or shotguns. They can either defend your base at night or be sent to conquer the wasteland.  They are not very good at the first job and I am not convinced the second job actually does anything beneficial for you. They never came back before the game crashed on me. 

Generals can be bribed so that a bunch of army guys will show up and sell you a bunch of guns at once. This is convenient since you can buy many guns while playing the minigame once. 

While your "base" has two stories in it, there is no reason to ever use the 2nd floor. Zombies can't fly and why add the travel distance? 

Anyway, I recommend not playing this game. Just watch the trailer and believe in the fantasy of what this game could have been.

review:
While I really want to like this game, sadly it is very broken and not even playable at some points. The game is dead for 5 years and the developer has abandoned it. Seems his account he connected the game to is heavily private and connected to an Russian account and Russian publisher who produces incomplete games connected to a Mega collection of shady games so I would not be surprised if he's a shady developer who produces very broken games to just sell. Plus it is manually put on sale, so he is actively trying to scam people with spring and summer sales, the hack. Almost a majority of the reviews are fake as well due to most of them having the early access tag connected to them, which is a common tactic to boost the rating before and after a games release.

As some people mentioned, it seems the game is using an earlier build of the game than what it should have released with. Plus several features the game was suppose to come with aren't even available such as the war room or the repair bench. Depending on what happens you could also get a crash either from raiders trying to raid your shop through a hidden influence counter and depending on either what gun you buy that require the repair bench OR if you sell guns in large qualities to groups. I've only managed to get one group to come in a buy weapons in bulk. The developer himself even tells people to just play the game and avoid the bugs through literal use of a guide on the forums ; which is stupid.

Don't buy this game. Just look for another game to spend your 1.99 (0.99 since it's seems to be always on sale).

review: This game is very interesting, but it need some fixes and I'm here to talk about that. So first things first, an update. This game hasn't had an update since 2017, it's been 3 years now. The game could definitely use some new content or mechanics, like for example, more weapons, store decorations or even if it's possible, a manual save system. The game just feels a bit dull and repetitive after a while, especially with the grey and dark atmosphere of the store and the mundane routine that starts to get remarkably boring a few hours into the game, so store decorations and more weapons would make the gameplay feel more varied and interesting. About the save feature, it's more of a second option if you can't add more variety into the game. Why is that, you might ask? Because if it does eventually get boring, I would want to quit or take a break from the game for a moment, but I can't do that if I'm in the middle of the day because all the progress would be lost, as the game only ever saves during your sleep. After all that, mores sprite would be cool too, as there's like 3 NPC sprites that are used over and over, and make the experience way more generic, so a few more sprites (say, 3 per type) would add a lot to the gameplay. Also, not important or necessary, but a bit more detail to the sprites themselves (if possible) would be nice. Like multicolor clothing, and more facial features (not things like eyes or mouths, as the game's art style is supposed to be more minimalistic). At last, one thing that would change the way the game feels is a more "durable" gameplay type. With manual saves, extra store features and ramp-up difficulty, the game would feel less like a disposable mini-game and more like a life-long experience that goes on forever and has more ways of keeping your progress. Overall, I can't give a rating because the game still needs a LOT more content to be considered "finished", even if it's no longer in development, it doesn't feel right to give a rating to something that needs more time to work.

review:
[h1]This is a gun trading game with some very minor base building and zombie defense. It's also buggy and unfinished.[/h1]

The base gameplay mechanic reminds me heavily of the [i]Taloon[/i] chapter of [i]Dragon Quest IV[/i]. In that chapter, you sit in your shop waiting for people to stop by your shop. Ultimately, you're saving money to fulfill a dream. Incidentally, I'm fond of that Chapter.

[i]Vendor Chronicles[/i] is rather similar. Except, there's no story or connection of any sort to the protagonist or the grand scheme of things. Also, you construct turrets and hire mercenaries to defend your little hide-out from the hordes of undead that aggressively visit you every few nights.

I suppose it's not that similar after all.

[h1]Simple, repetitive gameplay loop[/h1]

[list]
[*]Buy low and sell high
[*]Hire mercenaries for defense and "conquest"
[*]Sleep tight while...
[*]...zombies attack and your defenses blast them away
[*](if it's going too well, crash the game)
[/list]

Boy, that last part was annoying. Regretfully, it's not the only bug I ran into.

[h1]Bugs about trading...[/h1]

Buying and selling both play through the same mini-game of stopping the spinner at the right place. I noticed a bug that if you had several weapons of the same type and sold one, you'd somehow lose all of them instead of just the one.

[h1]Bugs about building...[/h1]

Then, if you were building something (likely a turret) when a zombie attack struck, the gameplay loop would get stuck, and no customers would arrive over the whole day. Only way to fix this was to restore the save.

[h1]Bugs about zombies...[/h1]

Game would sometimes randomly crash before or after the zombie attack. At least once this broke my save as well, forcing a restart from the beginning. After the second time I quit.

When zombie attack works (to be fair, it did most of the time), you can only watch the turrets and mercs (and potentially yourself) shoot at them and hope the defense is enough. There's no tactics involved, nor much strategy besides putting a lot of defenses ready.

[h1]Likely unfinished[/h1]

Besides all the bugs, there are also missing promised (according to Store page) features.

It seems that "the raiders" (supposedly human attackers) aren't implemented in the game, or they were removed lately, thus possibly rendering one achievement broken.

Repair bench was also removed before the final release due to bugs in its implementation.

It surely appears that the game has been released out of early access before properly testing and implementing all the intended features.

[h1]Other notes[/h1]

All of the above bugs and problems have already been reported in the forums with no response or action from the devs.

Music is okay but just one loop that gets boring after a while.

Pixel graphics is decent but repetitive: all zombies look the same, as do all the customers of certain type.

[h1]Disappointing conclusions[/h1]

After playing a few nights (and avoiding crashes) you can get an endless money flow underway but without a proper end game besides "conquering the wasteland".

This works by sending mercs on a mission. Then they'd bring weapons if successful or die trying, with nothing else to do to influence their mission. Since that's it, you'll have experienced all there is to the game in less than an hour.

There is (was?) some potential here but it doesn't look like the rest of it is ever going to be fleshed out. Thus, sadly I can't recommend it in its current state, even considering the inexpensive price.

review:
Desolate Wastes: Vendor Chronicles is a business simulation where you have to bribe your way through buying and selling guns while defending yourself from zombies and raiders.

In this game, you'll get people who will sell you guns, people who will buy guns from you, as well as others that have many guns to sell or purchase. To bargain with these people, you have to stop a wheel in a little section to get approvals. The more money you want to make/save, the more difficult it gets, as in, the more times you have to stop the wheel. There's also generals and mercenaries in the game too. You can bribe the generals, but I don't exactly know what it does. If you hire the mercenaries, you'll get protection from zombies and raiders. With the money you make, you can also build some things like turrets that will shoot at the zombies, but not the raiders for some reason. The visuals are okay and the audio is mainly gun sounds, so nothing out of the ordinary.

Some problems I have with the game is that when you build something and place it, you can't move it. This is a problem because now you're stuck with that one stool in the middle of nowhere that you aren't using or your bed is in a spot that makes you more vulnerable when you wake up from a zombie hoard coming for you. Also, there's a couple of bugs in the game too. One of the bugs I've encountered was something about an enemy. I'm not sure if it's an error with the raiders or not because I've never seen them appear in my game. Another annoying bug is that I can't access my saved game anymore because whenever I click on Load Game, my game shuts down. Also, I never saw the Workbench as an option for me to purchase and use, so I think that might be a reason I don't get any raider invasions.

This game is simplistic, but it doesn't provide anything else special. I don't recommend this game.

review:
Desolate Wastes: Vendor Chronicles is a bit of a different take on the post-apocalyptic genre than we're used to.  Sure it's still dreary and gray but rather than fighting your way through hordes of monsters you're running a small shop.  You still gotta mow down a few baddies along the way but most of your time is spent dealing with customers either requesting a specific type of gun or trying to sell you something they found.  You can negotiate the price and if you attempt to get a better deal, you usually have to play a game.  The game consists of a circle and an arrow spinning around it - land in the small colored section and you're one step closer to getting a good deal.  The harder the deal the more times you need to land in the correct spot - each time getting smaller and faster.  

As you make money from your deals you get the opportunity to build a few more items and add them to your shop.  Things such as a bar or gambling table - things that will net you extra money and allow you to hire some extra muscle to protect you.  And you'll need it as the game gets a bit more difficult and you may find yourself rushing to finish things and making a few errors here and there.

Desolate Wastes isn't the prettiest game.  It isn't the most intuitive.  But there's something charming and fun about it - at least for awhile.  If you're into resource management or trading type games then this will probably be something that interests you.  It's not gonna break the bank and you'll most likely get your money's worth.  

My first (poor) attempt at it: https://youtu.be/FwF4tEnvfl8

author: {'steamid': '76561198004120455', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1493242945}
review:
The conceit of the game is that you are running a gun store in a zombie apocalypse. That's a fine setup, but the execution is just a mess. The core of the game is buying guns at a low price and selling at a high price. Setting the price you want to offer is a fiddly mouse wheel (?!) adjustment. Then you play a minigame where you try to stop a spinning arrow within a colored area of a circle. The further away from the base price you've bid, the harder the minigame. It's not a very fun game and it really makes no sense in the game's fiction. It's just a system to add skill (of a sort) to negotiations. If you fail the game too many times, the other party leaves unhappy.

As you buy guns, you ought to place one of them under your pillow for the inevitable zombie invasion. Unfortunately, it's difficult to tell which slot is your pillow. When the zombies come, I seem to have used the least effective gun available. At first, I assumed I'd control the shooter, but it seems to be automatic. In any case, I have yet to survive an invasion. 

In the end, the mechanics kill this game. The concept is not nearly interesting enough to endure a tiresome minigame and counterintuitive interfaces. I'd skip this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007900616', 'num_games_owned': 2883, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1483594024}
review:
I personally purchased this game. I reviewed it for my 99 Cent Gaming series.

I went into this Early Access title completely blind not knowing what was in store. What I found was a pretty entertaining mini-game based arms dealer simulator that I enjoyed. As I discovered what made the game tick, I was able to let the slight grammar errors get a pass when the meat (or is that brains?) of the game play consisted of haggling for low buys and high sales.

While DW: Vendor Chronicles walks you through the basic set up of a bed, storage unit, etc, it doesn't really tell you how the game works, causing me to learn as I navigated through each menu, sale, offer, and barter session. Even though I enjoyed discovering the mechanics, I still felt lost for a good bit wishing I understood a few more basic concepts early on.

I only made it as far as the first zombie horde, which ended my life on two play throughs. In between I admit to enjoying the mini-game which consisted of stopping an arrow within a small box while it span in a circle. The circle, arrow and box shrunk the more times you had to land it which was dependent on the barter difficulty. It's very fun to test the limits of your eye sight...as it can get very very VERY small.

I have more to say in my first impressions video below, but overall I definitely feel that DW: Vendor Chronicles is worth the 99 cents it sells for. Definitely take the plunge now as it seems the developer will be adding to this promising Early Access title while also increasing the price.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ObPgibQ0D2o

review:
This is an addictive little trading game, and right now the price is screaming "buy me" :)

Ok, so the gist of it is buy low, sell high, protect your stuff from bandits and zombies.

This game isn't for everyone, as the trading system has a little minigame based on timing that may be difficult for some. When the trade begins, a circle appears... a marker flies around the circle, and you have to stop it within a certain area for a "success". This is repeated as many times as discerned by the "trade difficulty", a number set by your pricing offer on said trade.. I myself am not that great at the minigame, so I stay at difficulty 2.. and find that I make enough profit to get by.

Also, at the time I am writing this, there is a game breaking bug or two in the game that leads to crashes... mostly they're avoidable if you're aware of them, but they're annoying nonetheless. However, there was swift response from the developer on them, he seems to have a good idea whats wrong, and I'm hoping the bugs will be fixed rather soon after the holidays. I'll try to remember to edit this review once they're fixed.

Anyway, once the major bugs are fixed, this game is definitely worth a buy for its low price.

For now, I'm going to give a thumbs up, in the belief that the bugs will be fixed soon. Again, I'll try to remember to come back and edit this review if that ends up not being the case.
